entry.title: Is the coronavirus pandemic a chance to tackle climate change? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Is the coronavirus pandemic a chance to tackle climate change? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
As the world focuses attention on the coronavirus pandemic, experts are warning of a more dangerous threat: climate change. Our world continues to heat up faster than predicted. Small island nations are bearing the brunt. In a special episode in collaboration with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), we ask: can recovery from a global health crisis help heal our environment as well?
Presenter: Nick Clark
Guests:
Simon Stiell - Minister of Climate Resilience and the Environment in Grenada
Brooke Takala - Secretary General, Marshall Islands Red Cross Society
Jagan Chapagain - Secretary General, IFRC
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: US sanctions Lebanese allies of Hezbollah for first time

media:group.media:title: US sanctions Lebanese allies of Hezbollah for first time
media:group.media:description:
The United States has for the first time sanctioned Lebanese allies of Hezbollah. Two former ministers dismiss US accusations of corruption and providing material support to Hezbollah. Washington considers the Iranian backed group a "terrorist organisation" and accuses it of exploiting the state's resources. Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut, Lebanon.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Hezbollah #US #Lebanon

entry.title: US Justice Department seeks to defend Trump in rape case

media:group.media:title: US Justice Department seeks to defend Trump in rape case
media:group.media:description:
The US Justice Department has asked to take over President Donald Trump's defence in a defamation case brought by a prominent American columnist who accused him of rape. The unusual move means government lawyers would defend Trump at the expense of American taxpayers. The lawsuit was filed by advice columnist E Jean Carroll, who has accused him of sexual assault in an upscale department store fitting room in the 1990s. Trump called her a liar and claimed he had never met her.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Trump

entry.title: What’s being done to keep learning going in northern Nigeria? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: What’s being done to keep learning going in northern Nigeria? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
In observance of the first-ever ‘International Day to Protect Education from Attack’ on 9 September, The Stream is partnering with Witness to discuss a new documentary on the subject.
Ahmad the Architect follows Ahmad Buba, a man on a mission to help his native Nigeria undo the harm caused by Boko Haram, an armed group that doesn’t believe in Western education, and for more than a decade has bombed schools, killed teachers and kidnapped students. The film focuses on Ahmad’s efforts to build twenty four boarding schools for orphans of the violence and fourteen mosques.
According to UNICEF, the attendance rate in Northern Nigeria is roughly 53 percent. While Boko Haram is largely to blame for the lack of education, various other factors play into the abandonment of learning including lower value on the education of girls, joblessness and drug use.
In this episode of The Stream, we discuss the efforts to fix Nigeria’s debilitated education system and efforts to revive the schools.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#Aljazeeraenglish #News #ProtectEducationFromAttack

entry.title: Reopening of US colleges is ‘spreading COVID-19’

media:group.media:title: Reopening of US colleges is ‘spreading COVID-19’
media:group.media:description:
The World Health Organization says young people are now driving the spread of the coronavirus. But many university students across the US have returned to class despite that warning. The reopening of campuses resulted in thousands of new infections, but students say they are not to blame. Al Jazeera's Andy Gallacher reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Coronavirus #US

entry.title: Many homeless after Greece refugee camp destroyed by blaze

media:group.media:title: Many homeless after Greece refugee camp destroyed by blaze
media:group.media:description:
An overcrowded Greek island camp that had become a makeshift home for thousands of refugees is now a smouldering ruin. And a desperate effort has begun to decide what to do with those now homeless. Fire burned for hours through the Moria camp on the island of Lesbos into Wednesday morning. A state of emergency has been declared on the island and Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis is about to hold an emergency meeting in Athens. Al Jazeera's Laura Burdon-Manley has more.

entry.title: Afghan VP survives another assassination attempt

media:group.media:title: Afghan VP survives another assassination attempt
media:group.media:description:
Afghanistan's first vice president has survived what appears to have been yet another assassination attempt which killed at least 10 others. Amrullah Saleh is unharmed and thanked government security forces for what he called their fight against “terrorism”. Al Jazeera's Sara Khairat reports.

media:group.media:title: Iran may ban ‘luxury product’ imports
media:group.media:description:
Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has said that the government should act to stop the imports of unnecessary luxury products. But as Iranians suffer from US sanctions, the government is looking for ways to cut costs.
Al Jazeera’s Assed Baig reports from Tehran, Iran, on the outlook for these “luxury product” imports.

#Iran #Apple #iPhone

entry.title: England to limit gatherings to six amid coronavirus resurgence

media:group.media:title: England to limit gatherings to six amid coronavirus resurgence
media:group.media:description:
A surge in coronavirus infections in England has prompted the prime minister to introduce new restrictions. The number of people allowed to meet socially has dropped from 30 to just 6. And there are stronger localised measures in the town of Bolton, which has the highest case rate in the country.
Al Jazeera’s Paul Brennan reports from Bolton, UK.

#UKcoronaovirus #COVID19 #BoltonLockdown

entry.title: ASEAN summit: South China Sea, coronavirus pandemic cast a shadow

media:group.media:title: ASEAN summit: South China Sea, coronavirus pandemic cast a shadow
media:group.media:description:
The coronavirus pandemic and the South China Sea feud are high on the agenda for diplomatic talks in Southeast Asia. The 10-nation ASEAN bloc is holding a delayed summit, with foreign ministers meeting virtually due to the outbreak.
Al Jazeera’s Scott Heidler reports from Bangkok.

entry.title: California wildfires: Helicopters rescue more people from blazes

media:group.media:title: California wildfires: Helicopters rescue more people from blazes
media:group.media:description:
Wildfires, which California’s governor says have been spurred by climate change, continue to flare across the US state. Dozens of people had to be airlifted to safety on Tuesday, after more than 200 people were rescued over the weekend.
Al Jazeera’s Victoria Gatenby reports.

entry.title: Concern Peru COVID-19 death toll is higher than official figures

media:group.media:title: Concern Peru COVID-19 death toll is higher than official figures
media:group.media:description:
At least 30,000 people have now died from COVID-19 in Peru. That is one of the highest death rates per head of population in the world. But there is concern that the number of fatalities could be significantly higher than official figures suggest.
Al Jazeera’s Teresa Bo reports.

entry.title: Sudan floods: Calls for gov’t to help affected people

media:group.media:title: Sudan floods: Calls for gov’t to help affected people
media:group.media:description:
At least 110 people have now died from severe flooding in Sudan as the Nile river reaches unprecedented levels. Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced. The government has declared a three-month state of emergency.
Al Jazeera’s Hiba Morgan reports from Khartoum.

#Sudan #SudanFloods #PrayForSudan

entry.title: Daniel Prude: Rochester police officials step down amid criticism

media:group.media:title: Daniel Prude: Rochester police officials step down amid criticism
media:group.media:description:
The police chief of Rochester in the US state of New York has stepped down, along with top police leaders. It follows days of public outrage over the death of Daniel Prude, a Black man who died by suffocation while in police custody. Protests broke out after his family released last week body camera video and written reports of the March incident that they obtained through a public records request. Some viewers may find the footage disturbing.
Al Jazeera’s Mike Hanna reports from the US capital, Washington, DC.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
